body:
Well, the problem is that the UTF-8 encoding for that unicode character seems to be `\n', at least as I'm copy-pasting it out of GitHub:

```
In [15]: value
Out[15]: u'Id,StringCol\n7117434,Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is displayed in iphone simulator, Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is \ndisplayed in iphone simulator.Now we are adding the CSV file externally. I want to Call the File through the code..'

In [16]: value.encode('utf-8')
Out[16]: 'Id,StringCol\n7117434,Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is displayed in iphone simulator, Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is \ndisplayed in iphone simulator.Now we are adding the CSV file externally. I want to Call the File through the code..'

In [22]: list(csv.reader(StringIO(value.encode('utf-8'))))
Out[22]: 
[['Id', 'StringCol'],
 ['7117434',
  'Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is displayed in iphone simulator',
  ' Is it possible to modify drop plot code so that the output graph is '],
 ['displayed in iphone simulator.Now we are adding the CSV file externally. I want to Call the File through the code..']]
```

Can you send me the CSV file (wesmckinn _atttt_ gmail) so I can check against that?

Python actually isn't miscategorizing \u2028 as a newline-- the problem is the comma in an unquoted field. I would suggest a manual fix:

```
def read_fix_field(path):
    lines = [x.rstrip() for x in open(path, 'U')]
    fixed_lines = lines[:1]
    for row in lines[1:]:
        pseudo_fields = row.split(',')
        quoted_field = '"%s"' % ','.join(pseudo_fields[1:])
        fixed_lines.append(','.join((pseudo_fields[0], quoted_field)))
    return '\n'.join(fixed_lines)
```
